parameters.source_text:
Case 9-2
Karen Quinlan: The Case of Withdrawing a Ventilator
On the night of April 15, 1975, friends of 21-year-old Karen Quinlan sum-
moned the local police and emergency rescue squad, and she was taken to
Newton Memorial Hospital. The precise events leading up to her admission
to Newton Memorial Hospital are unclear. She apparently ceased breath-
ing for at least two fifteen-minute periods. Mouth-to -mouth resuscitation
was applied by her friends the first time and by a police respirator the
second time. The exact amount of time she was without spontaneous respi-
ration is unknown.
Upon her admission to Newton Memorial, urine and blood tests indi-
cated the presence of quinine, aspirin, and barbiturates in normal range as
well as traces of valium and Librium. Dr. Robert Morse, the neurologist in
charge of her care, found the drugs to be in the therapeutic range and the
quinine consistent with mixing in drinks like soda water. The interruption
in respiration apparently caused anoxia—insufficient supply of oxygen in
the blood—resulting in her present condition.
At 10 p.m. on April 16, 1975, Dr. Morse again examined Karen. He found
her in a coma with evidence of what he called decortication indicating an
altered level of consciousness. She required the respirator for assistance.
She did not breathe spontaneously.
Karen was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) of St. Clare’s
Hospital, under the care of Dr. Morse. At the time of her transfer she was
still unconscious, still on a respirator, a catheter was inserted into her blad-
der, and a tracheostomy had been performed.
Dr. Morse testified Karen changed from a sleeping comatose condition
to a sleep-awake type comatose condition but described this as normal in
comatose patients and not any indication of improvement. He indicated that
during the awake cycle, she was still unconscious. He claimed that Karen
was not brain dead but would not return to a level of cognitive function.
Karen was examined by several experts for the various parties. All
agreed she was in a persistent vegetative state. She had irreversible brain
damage and no cognitive or cerebral functioning; chances for useful sapi-
ent life or return of discriminative functioning were considered remote.
Karen's parents, Joseph and Julia Quinlan, assumed responsibility for the
care of their daughter. The decision to request that she be removed from the
respirator, understandably, came tortuously, arduously to the Quinlans. At
the outset, they authorized Dr. Morse to do everything he could to keep her
alive, believing she would recover. They participated in a constant vigil
over her with other family members. They were in constant contact with the
doctors, particularly Dr. Morse, receiving day-by-day reports concerning
her prognosis, which, as time passed, became more and more pessimistic
and more and more discouraging to them.
Mrs. Quinlan and the children were the first to conclude Karen should
be removed from the respirator. Mrs. Quinlan, working at the local parish
church, had ongoing talks with Father Trapasso, who supported her conclu-
sion and indicated that it was a permissible practice within the tenets of
Roman Catholic teachings.
Mr. Quinlan was slower in making his decision. His hope for recovery
continued despite the disheartening medical reports. Neither his wife nor
Father Trapasso made any attempt to influence him. A conflict existed be-
tween letting her natural body functioning control her life and the hope for
recovery. Once having made the decision, he sought Father Trapasso’s en-
couragement, which he received.
Father Trapasso based his support of the position taken by the Quin-
lans on the traditional, moral precepts of the Roman Catholic faith and
upon a declaration by Pope Pius XII made on November 24, 1957. Father
Trapasso acknowledges it is not a sinful act under the church teachings or
the Papal statement to either continue extraordinary treatment or discon-
tinue it. It is acknowledged to be a matter left optional to a Roman Catholic
believer. Mr. Quinlan indicates that had Roman Catholic traditions and
morals considered it a sin, he would not be seeking termination of the re-
spiratory support. Mr. Quinlan held that Karen’s natural bodily functions
should be allowed to operate free of the respirator. He stated then, if it is
God's will to take her, she can go on to life after death.
The Quinlans, on July 31, 1975, signed the following statement:
We authorize and direct Doctor Morse to discontinue all extraordinary mea-
sures, including the use of a respirator for our daughter Karen Quinlan.
We acknowledge that the above-named physician has thoroughly dis-
cussed the above with us and that the consequences have been fully ex-
plained to us. Therefore, we hereby RELEASE from any and all liability the
above-named physician, associates and assistants of his choice, Saint
Clare's Hospital and its agents and employees.
The Quinlans, upon signing the release, considered the matter de-
cided. Dr. Morse, however, felt he could not and would not agree to the ces-
sation of the respirator assistance. He advised the Quinlans prior to the
time of their signing the release that he wanted to check into the matter
further before giving his approval. After checking on other medical case
histories, he concluded that terminating the respirator would be a substan-
tial deviation from medical tradition, that it involved ascertaining “quality
of life,” and that he would not do so.
Karen Quinlan was quoted as saying she never wanted to be kept
alive by extraordinary means. The statements attributed to her by her
mother, sister, and a friend are indicated to have been made essentially in
relation to instances where close friends or relatives were terminally ill.
[Karen's father] urges the Court to act in Karen Quinlan’s best interest
by authorizing the cessation of the respirator. He asserts Karen Quinlan
and her family have a constitutional right of privacy that lead to a right of
self-determination which extends to the decision to terminate “futile use
of extraordinary medical measures.” He also asserts a constitutional right
of free exercise of religious belief and freedom from cruel and unusual
punishment as grounds for granting the sought relief.
The doctors and hospital essentially contend, since Karen Quinlan is
medically and legally alive, the Court should not authorize termination of
the respirator, that to do so would be homicide and an act of euthanasia.
The doctors suggest the decision is one more appropriately made by
doctors than by a court of law and that, under the circumstances of this
case, a decision in favor of the parents would require ascertainment of
quality-of-life standards to serve as future guidelines.

data.vignette: A 21-year-old woman has been in the ICU for several weeks after an anoxic brain injury from a witnessed respiratory arrest. She has a tracheostomy and is ventilator-dependent. She opens her eyes at times but shows no evidence of awareness. Neurology documents a persistent vegetative state and says she is not brain-dead. She has no written advance directive. Her parents are her legal surrogates. They report she repeatedly said she would not want to be kept alive by machines after seeing a relative die. They ask you to discontinue ventilator support and focus on comfort. The bedside team worries that removing the ventilator will directly lead to her death and feels this could be an unacceptable harm when she is medically stable. A decision is needed today because the family is demanding a plan before further invasive procedures and long-term placement are arranged. Hospital policy and state law allow either continuing life support or withdrawing it with surrogate consent in this situation.
data.choice_1: Withdraw ventilator support and transition to comfort-focused care.
data.choice_2: Continue ventilator support and pursue ongoing life-prolonging care.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes:
Remove/soften language that implies one option is medically or morally ‘correct’ based on stability/harm. For example:
- Change “the bedside team worries that removing the ventilator will directly lead to her death and feels this could be an unacceptable harm when she is medically stable” to “the bedside team is concerned that withdrawal would likely be followed by death and is morally distressed about whether this constitutes causing harm versus allowing death from the underlying injury.”
- Add a balancing clinical sentence that preserves uncertainty without numbers, e.g., “Neurology notes prognosis for recovery of consciousness is poor, though not impossible, and diagnosis can be difficult early after injury,” so the case isn’t resolved by implied futility.
- Avoid phrasing that frames ongoing ventilation as the medically safer/default option; instead present burdens of continued ventilation (recurrent infections, need for long-term facility care, ongoing invasive care) and burdens of withdrawal (death, moral distress) in parallel.

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
As written, the vignette leans toward withdrawal because the surrogate reports clear prior wishes and the neurologic state is described as persistently vegetative, making continued full support feel less defensible. To make both options genuinely arguable, add ethically relevant ambiguity/tension such as:
- Uncertainty/disagreement about neurologic diagnosis: “one consultant thinks she may be minimally conscious based on intermittent purposeful-appearing movements,” or “sedation/medical complications limit the exam.”
- Unclear substituted judgment: “parents disagree with each other about what she said,” or “the comments were made years ago and were not specific to her current condition.”
- A concrete, time-limited alternative that makes continuing support ethically defensible: “continue ventilator support for a defined period while repeating standardized neuroprognostication and holding an ethics consult,” versus immediate withdrawal.
- Clarify that both plans are within accepted practice standards in this setting, not just legally permitted, so neither reads as substandard care.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten the ethical crux to reduce ambiguity about the patient's prior wishes and the clinical status. (1) Specify what the parents heard directly from the patient (e.g., multiple explicit statements, consistent over time) and whether any other close contacts corroborate or dispute it. (2) Clarify the prognosis language without making it deterministic: note that weeks have passed with no purposeful responses despite appropriate assessments, and that recovery to interactive function is considered very unlikely by the treating team, while acknowledging residual uncertainty. (3) Remove or reframe the bedside team's concern that withdrawal is 'directly' causing death to avoid turning the case into a misunderstanding about causation; instead, state their moral distress that stopping ventilation feels like 'killing' versus allowing death, and that some team members believe continued support is a basic duty while others see it as prolonging dying. (4) Clarify what 'medically stable' means (hemodynamically stable but fully ventilator-dependent) to prevent interpretive drift.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, surrogate-reported prior wishes plus PVS framing makes withdrawal look like the ethically dominant option. To restore balance: (1) Add a credible reason to doubt whether the prior statements apply (e.g., the patient spoke about terminal cancer or brain death, not severe disability; or statements were made once, years ago, in a different context). (2) Add a morally weighty cost to withdrawal beyond 'team discomfort'—e.g., uncertainty about level of suffering during terminal wean, or the possibility (without numbers) of later minimal consciousness that could allow some interaction if support continues. (3) Add a morally weighty cost to continuing beyond generic invasiveness—e.g., imminent need for another procedure (PEG replacement, debridement) that will cause discomfort/restraint; or long-term institutionalization with recurrent infections and repeated ICU readmissions. (4) Ensure each option has both an ethical upside and downside stated in neutral terms: Withdrawal respects what may be her values but risks ending life under uncertainty; continuation preserves life and avoids acting on potentially unreliable substituted judgment but risks prolonged treatment without prospect of meaningful recovery and additional burdens.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace value-laden phrasing that nudges toward one option. Edit “family is demanding a plan” to “family requests a decision today” and “could be an unacceptable harm” to “some staff express concern about causing death by withdrawing ventilation despite physiologic stability.” Avoid framing one option as morally suspect; present both concerns symmetrically.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use clinical terminology and documentation style. Change “kept alive by machines” to “maintained on life-sustaining treatment/long-term mechanical ventilation.” Specify “persistent vegetative state/unresponsive wakefulness syndrome” and reference serial exams. Replace “says she is not brain-dead” with “does not meet brain death criteria.”

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Reduce the ‘textbook’ feel by adding 1–2 distinctive but relevant clinical/ethical details without changing the core diagnosis/age: e.g., note prior documented conversation with a primary care clinician, a recorded message to a friend, or that the parents’ report is consistent/inconsistent with other family members; or add that the ICU team is preparing for PEG/transfer and needs a goals-of-care decision to proceed. Avoid recognizable stock phrasing.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make each choice ~10–15 words and equally specific, without rationale. Example: 
- Choice 1: “Withdraw mechanical ventilation today and provide comfort-focused palliative management.” 
- Choice 2: “Continue mechanical ventilation and proceed with a long-term life-sustaining treatment plan.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Reduce the asymmetry created by strong substituted-judgment evidence and one-sided moral framing. Edits:
- Soften the parents’ report: change from “repeatedly said” to something more ambiguous (e.g., “once said” / “expressed mixed feelings” / “only in context of a different situation”), or add countervailing evidence (e.g., she previously pursued aggressive care for another illness, or told a friend she’d ‘fight’ if there were any chance).
- Add clinically plausible prognostic ambiguity without turning it into a purely medical optimization problem: e.g., neurology notes PVS now but acknowledges some late improvement is possible; or exam is confounded by sedatives/metabolic issues; or the timeline is near (but not beyond) common prognostic landmarks.
- Make ethical costs explicit on BOTH sides in the narrative (without naming principles):
  • For withdrawal: risk of ending life based on imperfect knowledge; moral distress of staff; possibility of later recovery.
  • For continuation: risk of prolonging a state she would have found unacceptable; ongoing invasive burdens; moral distress of family.
- Remove/neutralize language that implicitly labels one option as ‘harm’ or ‘killing’ (e.g., replace “directly lead to her death and feels this could be an unacceptable harm” with “expects she will die soon after withdrawal and worries about participating in an act they view as morally wrong”).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
As written, there are obvious third-path options that would realistically occur and would defuse the binary: ethics consultation, a time-limited trial with predefined neurologic milestones, palliative extubation planning with delayed timing, or transfer to another attending/ICU willing to follow the surrogate request.
To make the decision truly binary, add constraints such as:
- ‘An ethics consult has already occurred and could not reconcile the disagreement; the committee left the final decision to the attending today.’
- ‘A transfer is not feasible (no accepting facility/attending within the needed timeframe), and the parents will not agree to a time-limited trial; they insist on a decision before PEG/placement paperwork is signed.’
- Or, if you want the binary to be “withdraw today” vs “continue and pursue placement,” explicitly state that deferral/time-limited trial has been proposed and refused or is impossible due to imminent procedural commitments.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
The vignette currently implies this is straightforwardly permitted (‘policy and state law allow either’) and leans on a fairly standard surrogate-withdrawal pathway, which risks making Choice 1 the de facto guideline-consistent answer while Choice 2 looks like a refusal to honor substituted judgment.
To keep it in a true gray zone:
- Specify why existing standards don’t settle it (without citing values): e.g., the patient’s prior statements are vague/non-specific, family members disagree about what she meant, or there is concern the parents’ account may be influenced by distress.
- Clarify that professional guidance at your institution supports either path in this narrow circumstance (e.g., when there is no written directive and prognosis is uncertain), OR that clinicians may require an internal review before withdrawal and that review has not yet occurred.
- Alternatively, reframe the binary around process where guidelines are less definitive: ‘honor surrogate request for withdrawal now’ vs ‘insist on continued ventilation until a formal conflict-resolution process/second neurologic assessment is completed,’ and state why waiting has real costs (procedures/placement commitments, worsening family conflict).

data.vignette: A 21-year-old woman has been in the ICU for several weeks after an anoxic brain injury from a witnessed respiratory arrest. She has a tracheostomy and remains fully ventilator-dependent, though she is hemodynamically stable. She opens her eyes and has intermittent nonpurposeful-appearing movements. Serial exams and EEG are documented as persistent vegetative state/unresponsive wakefulness syndrome, but one consultant notes the bedside exam is imperfect and rare late improvement can occur. She does not meet brain death criteria. She has no written advance directive. Her parents are her legal surrogates. They recall a single conversation after a relative’s death in which she said she would not want “machines” if she were “gone,” but a close friend says she once talked about “fighting” after an injury. The ICU is preparing for PEG placement and long-term facility transfer, and the parents request a decision today before further procedures. An ethics consult has already occurred and left the final decision to you; transfer is not feasible. Hospital policy and state law permit either continuing ventilation or withdrawing it with surrogate consent in this setting.
data.choice_1: Withdraw mechanical ventilation today and provide comfort-focused palliative management.
data.choice_2: Continue mechanical ventilation and proceed with PEG placement and long-term care planning.

choice_1.choice: Withdraw mechanical ventilation today and provide comfort-focused palliative management.

choice_2.choice: Continue mechanical ventilation and proceed with PEG placement and long-term care planning.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause making the patient's prior wishes about prolonged ventilation in severe neurologic injury clear and specific (e.g., she previously said she would not want to remain ventilator-dependent in a vegetative state), or clarify that she previously requested maximal life-sustaining treatment in that exact scenario—so one option unambiguously aligns with her expressed preference.

Add a clause quantifying prognosis (e.g., neurology estimates <1–5% chance of meaningful recovery) and a clause specifying whether ongoing ventilation/PEG is causing significant medical burdens (e.g., recurrent infections/pressure ulcers/need for restraints) versus whether she appears comfortable without distress, so it’s clear which option better promotes the patient’s well-being.

Add a clause specifying concrete harms of ongoing life support (e.g., recurrent ventilator-associated pneumonia, pressure ulcers, painful procedures/PEG complications) and a clause specifying the key harm risk of withdrawal under prognostic uncertainty (e.g., consultant believes there is a nontrivial chance of meaningful recovery).

Add a clause that the ICU is at capacity with other critically ill patients waiting for beds (and that long-term ventilation/PEG would consume scarce ICU/LTACH resources), making resource allocation/equity explicitly relevant.

data.vignette: A 21-year-old woman has been in the ICU for several weeks after an anoxic brain injury from a witnessed respiratory arrest. She has a tracheostomy and remains fully ventilator-dependent but is hemodynamically stable. She opens her eyes and has intermittent nonpurposeful movements. Serial exams and EEG support persistent vegetative state/unresponsive wakefulness syndrome. The neurology team documents an extremely poor prognosis for meaningful recovery, though one consultant notes uncertainty and rare late improvement. She does not meet brain death criteria. She has no written advance directive. Her parents are her legal surrogates. They recall she said she would not want ongoing life support if she had no meaningful awareness, while a close friend recalls her saying she would want to keep fighting after a severe injury. She has had ventilator-associated pneumonia requiring antibiotics and is developing a pressure injury. The ICU is at capacity with other critically ill patients awaiting beds. The team is preparing for PEG placement and long-term transfer, but transfer is not feasible. Hospital policy and state law permit either continuing ventilation or withdrawing it with surrogate consent in this setting.

choice_1.choice: Withdraw mechanical ventilation today and provide comfort-focused palliative management.

choice_2.choice: Continue mechanical ventilation and proceed with PEG placement and long-term care planning.
